questions: You're at a casual team lunch when your skip-level manager unexpectedly joins. The conversation turns to what everyone thinks about the new reorg. What do you say?
During your annual review, your manager asks what you really think about the company's leadership. She seems genuinely curious and says it's off the record. What do you tell her?

You're chatting at a networking event when you realize the person you've been talking to is the hiring manager for a role you applied to. She asks what frustrated you most about your last job. What do you say?
Your company just announced they're piloting productivity monitoring software. In your next 1:1, your manager asks how you feel about it. What do you say?
You're in a video call with your team when the CEO silently joins. The discussion is about what's blocking your project. It's your turn to share. What do you say?
A journalist is writing a profile on your company and asks to shadow you for a day. During lunch, she asks what you'd change about the culture if you could. What do you tell her?
You're in the elevator with the head of HR when she casually asks how your team is handling the recent layoffs. What do you say?
During a conference coffee break, you realize the person next to you is a well-known industry blogger. She asks your honest opinion of the keynote speaker. What do you say?
Your company's internal survey says responses are anonymous, but you need to log in to complete it. The first question asks what's broken about your department. What do you write?
You're on a panel at an industry event and an audience member asks what mistake your company made that others should avoid. The CMO is sitting in the front row. What do you say?
A recruiter calls about a role at a competitor. Your manager walks by as you're on the phone. She asks who called when you hang up. What do you tell her?
You're at the holiday party when the CEO's spouse asks what you really think of working here. Your CEO is getting drinks nearby. What do you say?
During a team retrospective, the facilitator asks everyone to share one thing leadership could do better. Your director is taking notes. What do you share?
You're in a focus group about company culture and the moderator asks what's the one thing employees complain about most. The CHRO is observing through the glass. What do you say?
A board member visits your office and stops by your desk to ask how morale really is after the merger. What do you tell them?
You're being interviewed for an internal documentary about the company. The producer asks you to describe a time when leadership got something wrong. What story do you tell?
During onboarding, the training facilitator asks new hires to share their first impressions of the company so far. Your hiring manager is sitting in the back. What do you say?
You're at an alumni dinner and a former colleague now at a competitor asks what's really going on at your company. Your current coworker is at the same table. What do you share?
The town hall Q&A opens and you have a real concern about the new policy. The CEO invites honest questions and says there will be no retaliation. Do you raise your hand? If so, what do you ask?
Your mentor, who is also on the promotion committee, asks during coffee what you honestly think your weaknesses are. What do you tell her?
